title: A Randomized, Multicenter, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, 18-Month Study of the Efficacy of Xaliproden in Patients With Mild-to-Moderate Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to assess xaliproden's potential capacity of slowing the deterioration of cognitive and global functions in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. The patients participating in this study will take orally once daily xaliproden or placebo (inactive substance pill).
drug: xaliproden (SR57746A) — small-molecule 5-HT1A agonist with reported neurotrophic / neuroprotective effects
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests xaliproden to "slow the deterioration of cognitive and global functions" in mild–moderate Alzheimer's disease, i.e., an attempt at disease modification rather than only symptomatic relief. citeturn0search0

Act (drug identity/mechanism): Xaliproden (SR57746A) is a non‑peptidic small molecule that acts via 5-HT1A receptor–mediated signalling and has been described as having neurotrophic / neuroprotective effects. citeturn0search4turn0search9

Act (trial details): The study is a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase 3 trial (Sanofi) of once‑daily oral xaliproden vs placebo for 18 months (NCT record / trial registry). citeturn0search1turn0search0

Classification decision: Because xaliproden is a small‑molecule pharmacologic agent (not a biologic) intended to slow disease progression via neuroprotective/neurotrophic mechanisms, it best fits the "disease-targeted small molecule" category under the provided definitions. It is not a biologic, nor a purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric symptom treatment. citeturn0search4turn0search0

Reflect (ambiguity noted): Xaliproden does not directly target canonical AD proteins (amyloid or tau) per the cited mechanism; it is neuroprotective/neurotrophic. If the classifier required targeting amyloid/tau specifically to be "disease‑targeted," one could argue for ambiguity; however, by the provided category definitions (small‑molecule agents aiming to alter disease course/pathology), "disease-targeted small molecule" is the most appropriate label. citeturn0search4turn0search9
Web search sources used (summary): trial record and registry entries for the 18‑month Phase 3 study of xaliproden in AD (NCT entries / trial summaries). citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests xaliproden (SR57746A) as a disease‑modifying agent intended to slow cognitive/global decline in AD by neurotrophic/neuroprotective mechanisms rather than by directly targeting amyloid or tau.

Act (drug identity/mechanism): Xaliproden is a small‑molecule, selective 5‑HT1A receptor agonist with reported neurotrophic and neuroprotective effects mediated via MAPK/ERK and related signalling pathways. citeturn0search4turn0search0

Act (trial details): The study is a randomized, multicenter, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase‑3 trial (Sanofi) of once‑daily oral xaliproden for 18 months in mild‑to‑moderate AD (NCT00103649 / registry entries). citeturn1search1turn0search2

Classification decision: Because the intended mechanism and therapeutic aim are neurotrophic/neuroprotective (aiming to slow disease progression via synaptic/neuroprotective pathways) the best CADRO match is 'M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection' rather than a canonical neurotransmitter category. The drug acts at a neurotransmitter receptor (5‑HT1A) but the trial rationale and reported effects emphasize neuroprotection/neurotrophic action, which aligns with CADRO M. citeturn0search1turn0search4

Reflect: Alternative interpretation could place this under 'D) Neurotransmitter Receptors' because xaliproden is a 5‑HT1A agonist; however, CADRO seeks the most specific functional intent — here neuroprotection/synaptic support — so 'M' is more specific. If only receptor binding (with symptomatic aims) were emphasized, 'D' would be acceptable. The registry and mechanistic literature support the neuroprotective/neurotrophic interpretation. citeturn0search4turn1search1

Web sources used (selected): PubMed/primary mechanism studies showing 5‑HT1A‑mediated MAPK/ERK activation and neuroprotective effects of xaliproden. citeturn0search0turn0search1; A pharmacology review confirming high 5‑HT1A affinity and neurotrophic profile. citeturn0search4; Clinical trial registry entries for the Phase‑3 18‑month Sanofi xaliproden AD study (NCT00103649). citeturn1search1turn0search2
